People are up in arms in my Southwestern Ohio area about the impact of "The DaVinci Code". 
 
 Excerpt from the Cincinnati Enquirer:
 
 
 
"The story we tell is loaded with all sorts of hooey and fun kind of scavenger-hunt-type nonsense." - Tom Hanks, star, "The Da Vinci Code."
 
 
 "We're not frightened this is going to be so disruptive of people's lives they're going to abandon their faith." - Duane Davis, a community pastor at Vineyard Community Church.
 
 "For people whose faith is already weakened, and this comes along -- the devil just sits back and smiles." - Bob George, Kenwood, anti-"Da Vinci Code" prayer vigil volunteer.
 
 
 In 2,000 years, Christianity has survived many tests.
 
 The latest, it seems, opens in theaters today.
 
 The screen version of Dan Brown's multimillion-selling book "The Da Vinci Code" has only fueled debate over its elaborate, even lurid, version of religious history.
 
 In a letter that was distributed locally through fliers, e-mail, bulletin boards and churches, prayer-vigil organizers Bob George and Patrick Ashcraft linked the movie to "the raging cultural war that is devastating the soul of America."
 
 "Dan Brown ... like Osama bin Laden, has perhaps done more than anyone else to bring this cultural battleground to our own back yards," they wrote.
 
 ...
 
 Among other responses:
 
 Today's edition of the Catholic Telegraph weekly newspaper will carry a special four-page insert, prepared by the national publication Our Sunday Visitor, that takes on factual assertions. "The U.S. Conference of Catholic Bishops has been preparing for this for some time," said Dan Andriacco, director of communications for the Archdiocese of Cincinnati.
 
 "Prayerful protests" will greet moviegoers at several local theaters today, including Showcase Cinemas Springdale, Kenwood and Western Hills, as well as Northgate Cinemas and Rave Cinemas in West Chester.
 
 Latonia Baptist Church, Covington, will conduct a seminar at 7 p.m. Sunday based on material Pastor Stephen E. Hollaway compiled to counter "Da Vinci Code" lore.
 
 Vineyard will train volunteers (at 7 p.m. May 25 in the church's gym) to lead small home meetings. "We want to give people a platform to talk about the facts behind the fictitious story," Davis said.
 
 While many Catholic leaders have advised the faithful to stay away from the movie, Barbara Nicolosi, founder of the nonprofit company Act One, that trains Christians to create positive entertainment, is urging an "othercott" this weekend. Through her blog, churchofthemasses.blogspot.com, she encourages movie fans to go see any other film besides "Da Vinci" and thus dilute its box-office take.
